Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Neostigmine Reversal in Elderly Patients Undergoing Laparoscopic Pancreaticoduodenectomy

Participants.evidence: Elderly patients (≥65 years) undergoing elective LPD with cis-atracurium

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive neostigmine reversal or no reversal

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effect of neostigmine reversal on postoperative atelectasis and other complications

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of atelectasis within the first 3 postoperative days

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 501 patients were randomised: 89 to the neostigmine group and 213 to the control group

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 302 patients using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: Neostigmine reversal was associated with a lower incidence of atelectasis (OR 0.43, 95% CI 0.24–0.75, p = 0.003)

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported
